title: How to Make a Gluten Free Christmas Cake

steps.headline: Put the dried fruit and citrus zest into a bowl.
steps.description: Set a pot on the stove and put 2 cups (450 g) of currants into it along with 1 1/2 cups (340 g) of sultanas or raisins, 3/4 cup (55 g) of mixed peel, and 1/2 cup (50 g) of glace cherries. Add the zest of 1 lemon and 1 orange.Fruit variation: Swap out your favorite dried fruits for any of the fruits listed in the recipe. For example, try apricots, seedless dates, prunes, dried cherries, or cranberries.

steps.headline: Stir in the brandy or rum.
steps.description: Pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of the brandy or rum and stir until it's combined with the dried fruit. If you prefer, substitute whiskey or use orange juice for a non-alcoholic option. It's important to use an alcohol that has a rich, warm taste so it adds to the flavor of the fruit. Avoid substituting bitter or flavorless alcohol, such as gin or vodka.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium and stir the fruit occasionally as it heats. Cook the fruit until the liquid comes to a boil. This should take about 5 minutes. Keep the lid off of the pot while you're bringing it to a boil. Heating the fruit with the alcohol will soften the fruit so it absorbs the flavor faster.

steps.headline: Cover the fruit and soak it overnight.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and let the mixture cool to room temperature. Then put a lid on the pot and place it in the refrigerator to chill overnight. The fruit will continue to plump up and absorb liquid as it chills. To make the fruit in advance, store it in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 300 °F (149 °C) and grease an 8 in (20 cm) pan.
steps.description: Use a round cake pan with sides that are at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) deep. Rub a little butter inside the bottom and sides of the pan. Then cut a piece of parchment paper to fit the pan and lay it in the bottom. For a square-shaped cake, use an 8 in (20 cm) square pan.

steps.headline: Whisk the ground almonds, rice flour, corn flour, and spice in a bowl.
steps.description: Put 1 1/4 cups (150 g) of ground almonds into a mixing bowl with 1/3 cup (50 g) of rice flour and 1/4 cup (30 g) of corn flour. Whisk in 2 teaspoons (5 g) of mixed spice and ½ teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt until the dry ingredients are combined. Set the bowl aside.Did You Know? Some gluten-free flour mixes also contain fine polenta, chestnut flour, sorghum flour, and additional starches. Corn flour is also called cornstarch. If you prefer, purchase a gluten-free flour to use instead of the ground almonds, rice flour, and corn flour. Use a total of 1 3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (230 g) of the gluten-free flour mix.

steps.headline: Cream the butter with brown sugar in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Put 1 cup (225 g) of softened butter or vegan margarine into a mixing bowl and add 1 1/8 cup (225 g) of packed dark brown sugar. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed for 3 to 5 minutes or until the butter is pale and fluffy. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl occasionally. If you'd like to cream the butter and sugar by hand, use a wooden spoon and beat the mixture for 5 to 8 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix in the eggs.
steps.description: Crack 4 eggs into a small bowl and use a fork to beat them just until they're frothy. Then slowly mix them into the bowl with the creamed butter and sugar. Continue to beat the mixture until it's combined. This should take about 1 to 2 minutes. To make a vegan cake, substitute a mashed banana for the eggs. It's alright if the mixture looks curdled. It will become smooth when you add the dry ingredients.

steps.headline: Stir in the dry ingredients until they're incorporated.
steps.description: Turn the mixer down to low and slowly add in the dry ingredients. Keep mixing just until you don't see any traces of flour. If the batter appears too thick or stiff to stir, add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of warm water to loosen the batter. Don't worry about overmixing this Christmas cake. Unlike traditional Christmas cakes, this one doesn't contain gluten that could overdevelop and cause the cake to become tough.

steps.headline: Mix in the treacle, chopped almonds, and soaked fruits.
steps.description: Add 2 tablespoons (30 g) of black treacle or molasses and 1/2 cup (55 g) of roughly chopped almonds to the batter. Then open the container of fruit that you soaked and add it all to the batter. Stir just until all of the ingredients are combined. The batter should smell fragrant and spiced. If the smell is too faint for you, stir in another 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of mixed spice.

steps.headline: Spread the batter in the pan.
steps.description: Scoop the Christmas cake batter into the prepared baking pan and use the back of a spoon or offset spatula level the batter. This will help the cake bake evenly and will prevent it from forming a dome. To prevent the sides of the cake from becoming too dark, wrap cake strips around the outside of the pan.

steps.headline: Bake the cake for 3 1/2 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Put the filled cake pan into the preheated oven and bake the cake until it's set on top and it's completely cooked in the center. To test if it's finished, insert a skewer into the center of the cake. It should come out clean if the cake is done. If the top of the cake looks like it's getting too dark, lay a piece of parchment paper over the top of the cake as it finishes baking.

steps.headline: Flip the cake out onto a wire rack.
steps.description: Take a butter knife and run it around the sides between the cake and the pan. This will help loosen the cake. Then quickly flip the cake over so the top is facedown on a wire rack. Carefully lift the pan up and away. Wear oven mitts while you turn the cake out because the steam that's released will be very hot.

steps.headline: Cool the cake for 1 hour.
steps.description: Leave the parchment paper on the cake as it cools and keep the cake on the wire rack so air circulates underneath it. Cool the cake until it's at room temperature. This should take around 1 hour.

steps.headline: Poke holes across the cake and drizzle brandy over the top.
steps.description: Turn the cake over so the top is facing up. Use a skewer or toothpick to poke holes that are 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart over the top of the cake. Then take the remaining 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of brandy or rum and slowly pour it over the cake. The holes will help the cake absorb the alcohol evenly.

steps.headline: Wrap the cake and store it for up to 1 month.
steps.description: Although you could eat the cake immediately, the flavor will get better the longer it's stored. To store the cake, cover it tightly with 2 to 3 layers of plastic wrap and wrap it in 1 layer of aluminum foil. Keep the cake at room temperature in an airtight container out of direct sunlight.Tip: If you'd like to moisten the cake with alcohol, unwrap it carefully and spoon another 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of brandy or rum over the cake. Rewrap it and store the cake until you're ready to unwrap and serve it. You can do this once a month or skip it if you don't want to add alcohol. Remember to label the foil with the date you made the cake, so you can keep track of how long it's been maturing.

steps.headline: Cover the cake with your choice of decoration before serving.
steps.description: For rich decoration, roll out marzipan and lay it over the top of the cake. You can add more marzipan cutouts or sprinkle the top with powdered sugar. For a rustic decoration, leave off the marzipan, but scatter your favorite dried fruits and nuts on top. Then brush them with apricot jam to give them a little shine. Consider wrapping a festive ribbon around the sides of the cake to give it a finished look. To give your cake a snowy look, make a batch of royal icing and spread it over the top and sides of the cake. Swirl it to create peaks.
